gmd:definition.gco:CharacterString: Documentation of taxonomic sources, procedures, and treatments

gmd:rule.gco:CharacterString: New Metadata section as a class to MD_Identification

gmd:rationale.gco:CharacterString: The set of data elements contained within this class element represents an attempt to provide better documentation of taxonomic sources, procedures, and treatments.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: EnviroAtlas - Average annual soil loss and sediment yield to waterbodies by 12-digit HUC for the Conterminous United States

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: U.S. EPA Office of Research and Development (ORD) - Center for Public Health and Environmental Assessment (CPHEA)

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
This EnviroAtlas national dataset shows the average annual soil loss and sediment yield to waterbodies by 12-digit HUC subwatershed for the conterminous United States for 2011 with existing land use / land cover and under a scenario in which natural vegetation is removed. It also includes the soil loss and sediment yield prevented by natural vegetation, calculated as the difference between soil loss or sediment yield with existing land cover and under the vegetation removal scenario.
This dataset is based on a collection of six rasters showing runoff, sediment delivery ratio, and sediment yield to streams and waterbodies under two land cover scenarios. The two scenarios are the existing vegetation scenario based on the 2011 National Land Cover Database (NLCD), and a scenario in which natural land cover was replaced with barren land. Average annual soil loss due to sheet and rill erosion was calculated using the Revised Universal Soil Loss Equation (RUSLE) equation for both scenarios. A Sediment Delivery Ratio (SDR) was then applied to both scenarios. The SDR was multiplied by the average annual soil loss to estimate net sediment yield to downstream waterways under both scenarios. These datasets can be used together to quantify the soil retention services of natural vegetation.
The datasets used as inputs include the 2011 NLCD, 1971-2000 Rainfall-runoff erosivity factor from PRISM (Parameter-elevation Regressions on Independent Slopes Model), the U.S. Geological Survey's 30-meter digital elevation model (DEM), Soil Survey Geographic Database (SSURGO), and State Soil Geographic Database (STATSGO2) data, MODIS (Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer) Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI), and the US Department of Agriculture (USDA)'s crop management zones (CMZs).
This dataset was produced by the US EPA to support research and online mapping activities related to EnviroAtlas. EnviroAtlas (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas) allows the user to interact with a web-based, easy-to-use, mapping application to view and analyze multiple ecosystem services for the contiguous United States. The dataset is available as downloadable data (https://edg.epa.gov/data/Public/ORD/EnviroAtlas) or as an EnviroAtlas map service. Additional descriptive information about each attribute in this dataset can be found in its associated EnviroAtlas Fact Sheet (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas/enviroatlas-fact-sheets).

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: This dataset can be used to assess threats to the ecosystem services provided by soils, such as carbon sequestration, moderating floods, and growing food. This dataset can also be used to study the effects of erosion on streams and water bodies, and to analyze the ability of vegetation to reduce erosion. The overall goal of EnviroAtlas is to employ and develop the best available science to map indicators of ecosystem services production, demand, and drivers for the nation.

gmd:MD_RestrictionCode.codeListValue: None. Please check sources, scale, accuracy, currency and other available information. Please confirm that you are using the most recent copy of both data and metadata. Acknowledgment of the EPA would be appreciated.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: FGDC spatial domain

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Research and Development - Center for Public Health and Environmental Assessment (CPHEA), EnviroAtlas

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: 1. Acquired mean annual Rainfall-runoff erosivity factor (R) for 1971-2000 at 4 km resolution by request from the PRISM climate Group (Daly and Taylor, 2002).

2. Acquired the soil erodibility factor (K). The U.S. Geological Survey's Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) processed soil data for EnviroAtlas (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas) by converting the Soil Survey Geographic Database (SSURGO) erodibility factor (kffact) to a 30m raster, with gaps in SSURGO being filled with the State Soil Geographic Database (STATSGO2). All calculations done in SI, so the initial English units were converted to SI units (t ha hr / ha MJ mm), by multiplying the English units by 0.1317 (Foster et al., 1981). This was done in ArcMap when creating the RUSLE raster rather than writing a new Kfact raster with SI units.
3. Derived the slope length and steepness factor (LS).
3.a. Acquired the 30-meter digital elevation model (DEM) from the U.S. Geological Survey 3D Elevation Program (https://apps.nationalmap.gov/downloader/#/)

3.b. The Desmet and Govers (1996) LS factor method was implemented using the System for Automated Geoscientific Analysis (SAGA, http://www.saga-gis.org/saga_tool_doc/2.2.0/ta_hydrology_22.html) LS factor, Field Based module (Conrad et al., 2015). The LS factor was limited to a maximum of 72.15 as specified by RUSLE (Renard et al., 1997).
4. Cover-management factor (C) was estimated using the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI), assuming that as greenness decreases, erosion potential increases.

4.a. Used MODIS (Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer) NDVI values at 250m resolution for 16-day intervals between 2000 and 2014 (https://modis.gsfc.nasa.gov/data/dataprod/mod09.php) to calculate a mean annual NDVI.
4.b. Downscaled the NDVI to 30m resolution using the 2011 National Land Cover Database (NLCD, https://www.mrlc.gov/data/nlcd-2011-land-cover-conus-0).

4.c. Median NDVI was calculated for all NLCD land cover classes in each of 73 USDA crop management zones (CMZs) (https://fargo.nserl.purdue.edu/RUSLE2_ftp/Crop_Management_Templates/CMZ%20maps/CMZ%20map%20shape%20files/).
4.d. The median NLCD-level NDVI was applied to corresponding NLCD pixels in that land cover class/CMZ combination.

4.e. To relate NDVI to C, we used the generalized equation developed by Van der Knijff et al. (2000) for the European Union: C = γe^[−α (NDVI/β−NDVI)], where α=2, β=1, and γ =1. The α, β, and γ parameters were used to calibrate RUSLE average annual soil loss to the USDA 2015 National Resources Inventory (NRI) state-level cropland erosion by water estimates. Rather than using a single parameter set, calibration was performed spatially for the 73 CMZs. A total of 200,000 parameter sets were created using Latin hypercube sampling, with each set containing 219 parameters (a unique α, β, and γ for each CMZ). Parameter ranges were set to: α = [1, 8], β = [1,2], and γ = [0.2, 1] for cropland and α = [1, 8], β = [1, 2], and γ = [0.01, 0.7] for pasture. Spatially stratified samples of R, K, LS, and NDVI were drawn from each state's pasture/hay and cultivated crops NLCD classes, with a minimum of 1000 samples per state and class (number of samples were proportional to amount of pasture/hay and cultivated crops in the state). The RUSLE predicted average annual soil loss (Mg ha−1) calculated using each parameter set were compared to state-level NRI sheet and rill erosion by water estimates using the mean absolute error (MAE). Rather than using a single best parameter set, an ensemble average of parameter sets was used, in which the number of ensemble members was determined by minimizing the MAE. This process was completed separately for cultivated crops and pasture/hay NLCD classes, resulting in unique α, β, and γ for each class in each CMZ.

4.f. Using NDVI to calibrate C factor resulted in unrealistically high values for forest, grassland, wetlands, and developed areas. Therefore, C factors for non-agricultural NLCD classes were derived from literature.

4.g. A second raster was created to represent C-factors under a scenario in which current natural vegetative cover was removed. Replaced the C factors for forest (NLCD 41, 42, 43), shrub (NLCD 52), grassland/herbaceous (NLCD 71), and wetland (NLCD 90, 95) classes with the maximum C factor from barren land, applied uniquely for each CMZ. This was used to estimate sediment yield and sediment delivery ratio using the same steps described above.

5. The support practice factor (P) is not explicitly used here given the lack of a national database However, we expect that the impact of some support practices (e.g., winter cover crops, no-till, etc.) will be reflected in the calibrated C-factor using NDVI on cultivated cropland and pasture.
6. Calculated average annual soil loss (A) for both scenarios using the RUSLE equation (A = R x K x LS x C). P, the support practice factor, was not included.

7. Estimated Sediment Delivery Ratio (SDR) for both scenarios. RUSLE only predicts soil loss and does not account for off-site sediment yield. Therefore, the SDR was applied to the soil loss estimates from RUSLE to calculate estimated net sediment yield to downstream waterways. The SDR was calculated for each pixel in the CONUS using flow path connectivity. The methods used here are adapted from previous work by Hamel et al. (2015, 2017).

7.a. The Index of Connectivity (IC), defined here as a given pixel's connectivity to the nearest waterbody, was calculated using the ArcGIS Connectivity Index Toolbox (Cavalli et al., 2013, 2014, https://github.com/HydrogeomorphologyTools/Connectivity-Index-ArcGIS-toolbox/tree/master/ArcGIS10_3_Toolbox) based on the methods of Borselli et al. (2008).

7.a.i. Used TauDEM (Tarboton, 1997) to calculate upslope contributing area. This was used as an input in calculating IC. The downslope flow path was calculated using D8 flow direction along the steepest downward slope.

7.a.ii. The C factor was adjusted based on the disparity of low sediment generation by impervious surfaces versus the greater potential for connectivity due to those impervious surfaces. Therefore, the NLCD Urban Imperviousness 2011 dataset (https://www.mrlc.gov/data/nlcd-2011-percent-developed-imperviousness-conus-0) was used to represent developed land cover C factors. Imperviousness in the original dataset ranges from 0 to 1; these values were used directly for the developed land cover C factor, allowing them to vary from pixel to pixel. The mean C factor values increased with increasing density: 0.05 (developed, open space), 0.3 (developed, low intensity), 0.61 (developed, medium intensity), 0.88 (developed, high intensity). In the initial C-factor datasets, if NLCD 2011 land cover pixel = class 21, 22, 23, 24, we replaced the C-factor value for that pixel with the NLCD 2011 percent impervious value. In some cases, the class is 21-24, yet the imperviousness is 0%. The minimum W-factor value is 0.001. Therefore, C-factor 0 values that were not water (NLCD 11) are replaced with 0.001 in the final W-factor rasters.

7.a.iii. Sinks (delivery endpoints) were defined using the National Hydrography Dataset Plus Version 2 (NHDPlusV2, http://www.horizon-systems.com/nhdplus/NHDplusV2_home.php) streams and waterbodies, converted to a binary raster where sinks = 1 and everything else is nodata.

7.b. The SDR for pixel i is then calculated using the equation SDRi = SDRmax,i / {1 + exp[(IC0-ICi)/kb]}. SDRmax,i is the maximum possible delivery ratio for the ith pixel, defined as the fraction of topsoil particles finer than coarse sand (less than 1 mm in diameter) (Vigiak et al., 2012), derived from SSURGO and STATSGO2. In rare cases where data were missing, we set SDRmax,i = 0.8. IC0 was set to 0.5 and kb was set equal to 2 (Vigiak et al., 2012, Borselli et al., 2008). Since the connectivity index tool does not calculate values for pixels that border sinks, these pixels were filled with SDRmax.
7.c. Sediment yield from each pixel was then calculated as the product of RUSLE's average annual sheet and rill erosion (A) and the SDR.

8. Determined how much sediment is retained by natural land cover by comparing the scenario with existing vegetative cover to a scenario where current natural vegetative cover was removed. The difference shows how much erosion is prevented by natural vegetative cover.
9. Summarized the results by 12-digit HUC using the EnviroAtlas version of the NHDPlus V2 WBD snapshot.
